     Head P - Ministry of Home Affairs (cont.) ---

 

     Resumption of Debate on Question [11th March, 2004],

   

      "That the total sum to be allocated for Head P of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, may I just respond to some of the points raised by Members concerning homeland security and terrorism yesterday before we adjourned.

 

     Sir, international terrorism remains a significant threat to global security in spite of increased efforts by many countries, including Singapore, to combat terrorism. Al-Qaeda is believed to retain the capability and intention to mount terrorist attacks, and its ability to inspire like-minded terrorist organisations and radical individuals to become instruments of terror has not diminished.

 

     Terrorist attacks remain unabated. In May last year, suicide bombers attacked residential estates in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, causing heavy casualties. Six months later, suicide bombers struck Riyadh again, also targeting innocent civilians. Just yesterday, the European Union experienced its worst terrorist attack in recent history in the Madrid train bomb blasts. These attacks not only underscore the ruthlessness of terrorists in their determination to harm innocent civilians, but also demonstrate the extent of our vulnerability. In addition to attacks on land, the possibility of a major aviation or maritime attack by terrorists, which will result in severe loss of human life and dire economic consequences, cannot be ruled out. Terrorists have even explored the use

Column: 1298

of chemical and biological weapons in attacks.

 

     Sir, closer to home, terrorist organisations like the Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) and Abu Sayyaf Group continue to pose a significant threat to security in our region. The suicide bombing attack of the Marriott Hotel in Jakarta in August last year is a case in point, as it is the worst attack in the country since the suicide attacks in Bali in 2002. "Soft targets" remain the greatest risk of another attack, as terrorists, who are constantly on the look-out for opportunities to carry out their operations, face more obstacles in targeting hard or heavily fortified targets like embassies. The Philippines continues to experience sporadic incidents perpetrated by suspected militants, while southern Thailand recently faced a spate of attacks early this year beginning with a raid on one of its military armouries.

 

     Mr Ravindran has asked for an assessment of the terrorist threat faced by Singapore. Terrorism still poses the gravest threat to our country's security. Singapore remains a prime target for attack. The regional JI terrorist group has not been eliminated despite the arrests of key JI terrorists like Hambali and Arifin Ali and our crippling of the local JI network through a series of security operations that began in December 2001. The most recent one was the January 2004 detention of two more JI members and the placing of restriction orders on 12 Singaporeans.

 

     JI militants, like Azahari Husin (who is an expert bomb maker), Noor Din Mohd Top, Dulmatin and Zulkarnaen remain at large, and are reportedly planning more terrorist attacks. Another concern is that the JI has shown itself to be a resilient organisation, which is already grooming its next generation of leaders and operatives. This is evident in the recent discovery of the JI "Al Ghuraba"

Column: 1299

(foreigners) cell in Pakistan in September 2003. What is more disturbing is that the arrests in Pakistan indicate that the next generation of JI leaders, if they are not stopped in their tracks, would be "better educated" and better trained. They would have undergone a more structured religious indoctrination at radical madrasahs, and trained with established foreign militant groups like Al Qaeda and Lashkar-e-Tayyiba. Moreover, the fact that the JI has gone beyond Southeast Asia into South Asia demonstrates its resourcefulness and ability to network with other terrorist groups.

 

     Mr Ravindran also asked about our state of readiness in preventing terrorist attacks in Singapore. We are well prepared. Till now, we have been able to stop planned attacks by using a combination of good intelligence, international cooperation and security measures, which we review regularly to keep pace with the changing conditions.

 

     Mr Ravindran also raised the issue of whether our security agencies have become better at sharing intelligence. Intelligence sharing is not new. After September 11, we strengthened our inter-agency cooperation on counter-terrorism. A Joint Counter-Terrorism Centre, hosted by the Internal Security Department (ISD) and the Security Intelligence Division (SID), was set up to provide intelligence assessment on terrorism. ISD's Counter-Terrorism Research Division maintains a round-the-clock website for the security and intelligence community in Singapore. This website houses a terrorism database and postings of the latest terrorist threat alerts and information for immediate dissemination to all significant parties who need to know.

 

     Sir, let me update the House on some of the key measures we have taken to strengthen security. First, we have imposed 100% security screening of visitors and vehicles entering Singapore

Column: 1300

by land since March 2003 to prevent terrorist infiltration and the smuggling in of arms and explosives. We make good use of technology to ensure effective checks, despite the heavy volume of visitors and vehicles. For example, radiographic scanners are deployed to screen sea cargo at PSA sea terminals at Tanjong Pagar and Pasir Panjang. We will buy more such scanners to beef up our cargo screen capacity at our checkpoints.

 

     Second, we have enhanced security for critical installations and "hardened" "soft targets" in Singapore. Recently, enhanced security measures were taken at areas where large numbers of people congregate, such as Mohamed Sultan Road, to minimise the possibility and impact of bomb attacks.

 

     Third, we are acting to deter terrorists from mounting unconventional attacks in Singapore. Licences are now required for the import, transport and storage of flammable substances such as magnesium and hydrogen over a certain threshold quantity. We have also taken steps to prevent terrorists from gaining access to dual-use goods like explosive precursors, radioactive substances and toxic materials. A security review of critical biological laboratories has been carried out to reduce the likelihood of terrorists getting hold of highly contagious pathogens from the laboratories in Singapore.

 

     Dr Mohamad Maliki has asked if the enhanced security measures have affected the productivity at our checkpoints. In the current global security environment, Singapore is not the only country that must balance efficiency with security needs. With the ongoing terrorist threat, we must build security considerations into the way we conduct commerce and businesses. Members may recall that last year, I informed the House that as we stepped up security checks at our checkpoints, some inconveniences

Column: 1301

might be experienced during peak hours. But the occasional inconveniences are but a small price to pay to enhance our security. Let me add that our officers at the border control points have done very well in responding to the added security demands placed on them.

 

     Sir, the Government has done much to protect Singapore against terrorist attacks. But the war on terror is a shared responsibility between the Government and our people and businesses. Everyone must be aware of the terrorist threat and play his part in fighting terrorism. In the White Paper on the JI that we tabled here last year, the Government had asked Singaporeans to approach the authorities if they were aware of terrorist or other suspicious activities. I am pleased to report that Singaporeans have indeed become more alert. Last year, the authorities received some 120 calls, that is, one call every three days, from members of the public about suspicious people or vehicles. Such efforts increase our chances of busting yet another terrorist plot or attack.

 

     It is also important to strengthen our social cohesion and resilience as a society, so that Singaporeans are strong enough to carry on with their lives, even if a terrorist incident were to take place. To achieve this goal, my Ministry works closely with other agencies, such as MITA, which drive mass-awareness programmes and public education efforts like the "Anti-Terrorism Preparedness Workshops" at the constituency level.

 

     The Home Team is also engaging the community directly on security issues. For example, we have conducted nearly 1,000 briefings to build awareness of the terrorist threat and encourage everyone to assist the Government in combating terrorism. For the business community, in particular, the briefings seek to increase

Column: 1302

their security awareness and encourage them to take ownership of their own security. After the Jakarta Marriott Hotel bombing last year, about 300 CEOs and senior management of hotels and major commercial buildings were briefed, and given a security handbook "Guide to Securing Your Organisation's Security". I was encouraged to note that our efforts had been effective when I read a Straits Times' article on 10th December last year that hotels were treating the terrorist threat seriously, and were beefing up security on their premises. Some had set up clusters to coordinate anti-terror responses, while others had implemented security measures like restricting parking at critical frontages or erecting anti-charging barricades to deter vehicles from charging in.

 

     For the general community, our efforts are aimed at educating everyone about the security threat and the measures that they can take to prevent and respond to terrorist attacks. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) plays a key role in these efforts. It has refocused the theme of its Community Emergency Exercises to prepare the community for a terrorist attack. It has also enhanced the role of its civil defence volunteers. The Home Team, together with the People's Association, will build on the network of civil defence volunteers, in rolling out a new grassroots programme to prepare residents to deal with such emergencies as infectious disease outbreaks, water shortages and bomb blasts. I am pleased to note that the idea of forming teams to deal with emergencies was suggested by the grassroots leaders themselves - it indicates that our efforts to involve the community in security are making good progress.

 

     The Singapore Civil Defence Force formally introduced the In-place Protection Procedure to public housing during Civil Defence Day in September last year, to help residents protect themselves against

Column: 1303

a hazardous materials release or terrorist attack. The in-place protection procedure is being progressively extended from residential buildings to commercial and industrial ones through their Fire Safety Managers. In January this year, the occupants of some 13 commercial buildings around the Raffles Place MRT station successfully exercised the in-place protection procedure during a multi-agency exercise simulating the release of a chemical agent within the station. The SCDF will engage more companies this year to guide them in designing in-place protection plans.

 

     The Police also engage the community on security threats. They have distributed information pamphlets on counter-terrorism responses and instituted target-hardening mobilisation exercises. To-date, 51 Security Watch Groups, comprising representatives from

357 buildings, have been formed to encourage private building owners and security managers to implement target hardening measures.

 

11.15 am

 

      Dr Mohamad Maliki asked whether we use a colour code in our public alert system like some other countries, for example, the United States.  No, we do not.  Instead, we inform those who are the potential target of a terrorist attack directly and quickly so that they can swiftly take the appropriate preventive and protective measures.  This approach has served us well.  It ensures that we do what we need to do, without generating unnecessary anxiety among the general population.  If not, every time we raise a code, people get anxious; we bring it down, they will say, "Times are back to peaceful time again", and so on.  That would cause a lot of anxiety to our population.

 

     Although our security measures are resource-intensive, I would like to assure Prof. Chin and the House that our success

Column: 1304

on the terrorism front has not come at the expense of Police law enforcement duties.  The Police has made the organisational adjustments to meet the surge for manpower, for example, by increasing recalls of operationally ready National Servicemen and deploying officers in staff positions to operations.  I would elaborate on this later on.

 

     Sir, international cooperation is a vital component in the fight against terrorism because terrorism is a transnational problem which no country can fight alone.

 

      My Ministry has been sharing intelligence about terrorist identities, movements and activities with other countries.  This has contributed to several successes, such as the arrest of the JI members, like Hambali, Fathur Rohman Al-Ghozi, Arifin Ali and the Singapore JI leader, Mas Selamat Kastari, in our neighbouring countries.  Arifin's arrest had in turn led to the discovery of a terrorist plot to bomb certain embassies and targets in Bangkok, and the Singapore Embassy was one of those targets.  This gave the Thai authorities the lead to investigate and arrest the culprits before they could complete their planning, thus averting a tragedy.

 

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked about our cooperation with the Malaysians and the Indonesians.  I wish to inform Members that cooperation with the Malaysians has been invaluable in our efforts against the JI.  The Malaysians were the first foreign intelligence counterparts that ISD alerted on the JI case.  We gave law enforcement officers from Malaysia and Indonesia access to our JI detainees to assist them in their investigations.  We also assisted the Indonesian authorities in their prosecution of cases by allowing the detainees they had interviewed and who were willing to testify through video-conferencing at the trial of Abu Bakar Bashir.

Column: 1305

 

     International cooperation is critical also in the area of aviation security.  Our air marshals are operationally ready and are flying to selected countries, providing security cover to our national carriers.  This arrangement allows us to meet foreign demands for protection for our national carriers flying to other countries.  We are also working towards developing a protection system for our airlines against the threat of surface-to-air missiles.

 

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked what my Ministry has done to deal with the threat of maritime terrorism and piracy.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo has also asked on the extent that our Police Coast Guard (PCG) has beefed up its resources.

 

     Within Singapore waters, Sir, the Police Coast Guard undertakes law enforcement and security policing.  Mdm Ho would be assured to know that the PCG has increased its manpower establishment by 134 permanent posts, so that the security operational deployment within our Singapore territorial waters will be strengthened.  PCG has also developed projects to boost its training and operational capability.  These projects include enhancing surveillance and monitoring capabilities, and buying new training simulators to improve the realism and the scope of training  options for our PCG officers.  All these projects serve to improve the effectiveness and professionalism of our PCG officers.  The PCG will continue to upgrade its capabilities to face new challenges.  On the landward side, the security of facilities serving maritime assets has also been enhanced. 

 

     The Police Coast Guard's strong enforcement efforts have been highly effective.  One measure of success is that since 1990, there has been only one reported sea robbery incident within our Singapore waters.  We have also received

Column: 1306

intelligence that the stepped-up measures to safeguard our territorial waters have made it difficult for human smuggling syndicates to convey illegal immigrants to Singapore by sea that they now have to resort to asking the illegal immigrants to swim to our shores under the cover of darkness.

 

     Sir, we have also taken a serious review on our port security.  The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is implementing security measures to meet the International Maritime Organisation's (IMO) newly introduced International Ship and Port Facilitiy Security (ISPS) Code.  In the pipeline are other proposals like the need for all vessels, including Singapore registered small craft, to be fitted with transponders to let authorities identify them electronically.  This is beyond the IMO requirement for identification transponders for vessels above 300 gross tonnes.

 

     Nonetheless, Mr Yatiman and Mr Tan Soo Khoon correctly pointed out that there has been an increase of piracy attacks, and a real risk of terrorists collaborating with pirates outside Singapore territorial waters, especially in the Straits of Malacca.  This is a vital waterway not only for us but also to the world.  International and regional cooperation is key to preventing terrorist attacks and piracy and ensuring the safety of our sea lanes.  One international initiative to address piracy is the Regional Cooperation Agreement on Anti-Piracy in Asia (ReCAP).  All ASEAN nations, Japan, China, Korea, India, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka are working under ReCAP to set up an information network and a cooperation regime to prevent piracy and armed robbery against ships in the regional waters.  We have worked closely with our neighbours too.  One such example is the IndoSin Coordinated Patrols, a bilateral anti-sea robbery cooperation between Singapore and Indonesia, involving both the navies and police coast guards. 

Column: 1307

 

     Mr Yatiman Yusof and Mr Tan Soo Khoon also mentioned the dire consequences if a tanker were hijacked and used as a bomb as it is piloted towards our shores.  To minimise this threat, vessels deemed to be of higher risks must give a 24-hour advance notice of their arrival, and are required to move along specific designated routes.  Their movements are closely tracked using our Vessel Traffic Information System and the Automatic Identification System by the MPA.  As a deterrent, the Navy also carries out selective escort of high value or high risk vessels through the Singapore Straits.

 

      As piracy attacks and maritime terrorism grow in sophistication and complexity, we need to adopt a multifaceted approach on maritime security and to strengthen our linkages with the Government agencies.  I would like to assure the House that my Ministry works closely with the Ministry of Defence, Ministry of Transport, the Maritime and Port Authority in maritime security.  DPM and Coordinating Minister for Security and Defence, Dr Tony Tan, recently announced the creation of a high-level Maritime Security Task Force to tackle piracy and to further strengthen our maritime security.  The Task Force has identified a number of preliminary tasks, including strengthening multilateral cooperation, enhancing coordinated patrols and other operational measures to deal with the issue of maritime terrorism, and enhancing law enforcement to deal with piracy.

 

     Sir, the Government has put in place a strategic National Security Framework, which enables strategic policy coordination and intelligence sharing among the Home Team, MINDEF, SAF and other Government agencies involved in security and counter-terrorism.  This synergy, among these agencies, has been greatly enhanced since September 11, with the creation of new outfits, such as

Column: 1308

the National Security Task Force, the Homefront Security Office and the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority.  These structures enable us to integrate our counter-terrorism efforts and streamline coordination between MINDEF, MHA and other Government agencies.  Nevertheless, DPM and Coordinating Minister for Security and Defence, Dr Tan, is currently leading a review of our Strategic Framework for National Security to make our policy coordination and intelligence sharing even more seamless and sustainable in the long term.

 

     Within my Ministry, we have reviewed our operational coordination framework to dovetail the overall strategic framework review.  Sir, since 1978, the Government has an inter-agency management structure called the Executive Group (EG), which is tasked to manage all civil security-related incidents.  The EG is headed by my Ministry comprising the Permanent Secretaries of Ministries and Chief Executive Officers of statutory boards.  It has been successfully tested in such crises as the rescue efforts when Hotel New World collapsed in 1986, and the hijacking of SQ 117 in 1991.  It has met regularly over the years to discuss contingency plans for managing crisis situations for a wide range of scenarios including terrorist bomb explosions, hostage situations, aircraft hijacks and civil emergencies, like building collapses and air crashes.  More recently, the EG was activated to help the Ministerial Committee to manage the SARS crisis.  It is currently maintaining an oversight on the Avian flu situation, and coordinating the inter-agency contingency plans to handle an outbreak, if one should occur in Singapore.

 

      Sir, my Ministry has reviewed the crisis management structure in order to improve it.  The Ministerial Committee, which I chair as the Minister for Home Affairs, will be formalised as part of our crisis management framework.  It will

Column: 1309

provide policy guidance during a national crisis.  The Ministerial Committee will be named the "Homefront Crisis Ministerial Committee", while the Executive Group will be renamed the "Homefront Crisis Management Executive Group" and its scope expanded to deal with all civil contingencies, including security related ones.  Multi-agency subgroups that report to the Executive Group can be formed, where necessary, so that cross-agency issues can be coordinated and resolved quickly.  A Homefront Crisis Management Centre will be established to support the Ministerial Committee and the Executive Group to maintain the latest situation pictures and perform horizon scanning of emerging potential threats.  The enhancement to the crisis management structure will enable my Ministry to plan for contingency responses more holistically.

 

11.30 am

 

     Sir, our multi-pronged strategies and integrated approach towards security have thus far kept the threat of terrorism at bay.  The right against terrorism will be for the long haul because terrorism has become a global and regional phenomenon.  Dr Mohamad Maliki would be happy to hear that we will continually adjust our strategies to suit changing conditions and seek international cooperation

to narrow the space for terrorists to operate.  However, whilst the Government can take all the necessary measures, we need the public and the business community to be firmly with us as strategic partners in the fight against terrorism.  I am confident that we can win this fight, just as we have overcome the deadly SARS with our tenacity, determination and unity.

     Youth Crime

 

     Mr R Ravindran (Marine Parade):  Sir, when the police force recently released

Column: 1310

the crime statistics for 2003, I noticed that there was a slight increase in youth crimes.  I am very concerned whenever there is a rise in youth crime because, if we can check youth crime, we will prevent many youths from progressing to become adult criminals. 

 

     As such, I would like to ask the Minister whether any study has been done to identify the causes, and also to develop new strategies to deal with youth crime.  In particular, I would like to ask whether many of these crimes are related to gang activities.  I would also like to ask the Minister how MHA deals with schools, the community and families to help youths to prevent them from committing criminal acts.  How does the MHA deal with youth offenders?  Do all youth offenders get charged in court or do they get warnings and are given a second chance, because we do not want to spoil the future career of youths by charging them at a young age and getting a criminal record?  What is the approach in dealing with youth offenders?

     Mr Ahmad Khalis Bin Abdul Ghani (Hong Kah): Sir, in addition to the questions from the speaker before me, can the Minister enlighten us on the trends of crime involving youths, say, for the last few years?  Is it true that more teenage girls are getting involved in gang-related activities?  What are the lessons that we can learn from these trends and what efforts have been made to arrest such unhealthy trends?  From the information culled thus far, are we able to have a profile of the youths who have a high risk of being involved in delinquency or crime?  Having such a profile would enable the authorities to direct their efforts in a more effective manner and to take more preventive upstream measures.  This should reduce the problem in the longer term.  Is the Minister able to share with us the profile of such high risk groups?  If the Minister is not disposed to do so, could he see whether the profile

Column: 1311

information could be shared in confidence with relevant persons, such as school principals or grassroots or community leaders? 

 

     As spoken earlier, there are other aspects to these issues besides legal enforcement.  Delinquent behaviour could be related to family, social or school problems.  Curbing delinquent behaviour among youths therefore requires the coordinated involvement of several parties, including the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Ministry of Community Development and Sports, schools and even parents.  Would the Minister agree that such a coordinated and comprehensive approach would be more effective and, if so, are there efforts being made in this regard?

     Mr Heng Chee How (Jalan Besar): Sir, building on the comments from the two colleagues who spoke before me, I also note with concern the rise in the figures for youth crime.  I think it is important that we try to guide our youths on to the right path, so that they do not develop into adult criminals.  In this connection, I would like to ask the Minister whether there has been any correlation between the increase in youth crime and the growing attendance of our young people at entertainment venues, and also whether or not there is a correlation between the increase in youth crime and the increased use of drugs by young people.  I say this because, even as our society frees up, I think we have to strike a very good balance between allowing for more fun and not wanting to jeopardise the future of our young people, but at the same time maintaining the overall discipline of our society.

          The Chairman:  Proceed with your next amendment, Mr Heng.

     Loan Sharks

 

     Mr Heng Chee How:  Sir, we hear regularly of the trauma that residents face

Column: 1312

as they are harassed by loan sharks.  In many of these cases, the loan sharks harass those families because certain members of the family have taken loans from them and have not paid up on time and so on.  At the same time, I also hear regularly of families whose members did not borrow from loan sharks, and those families include instances where they had purchased flats from other households, and then the loan sharks may be actually pursuing people who had borrowed from them but who had been members of the previous household, the one which had sold the flat to them.  I also notice that there had been instances where it seems that different loan sharks pursue and harass these families, suggesting that the borrowers, after they had sold the flat, had continued to use the old identity card in order to take up new loans with different loan sharks, therefore, causing more harm and harassment for innocent parties. 

 

     In this connection, I applaud the stepped up efforts of the police in curbing loan sharking and in arresting the loan sharks.  At the same time, I would like to ask the Minister whether more efforts are being done to track down these borrowers and, in particular, those who had borrowed using identity cards that have not been updated, and whether besides constituting an offence under the National Registration Act for not changing the address on time, there are other offences such people may have committed and therefore other penalties would then apply.

     Alternatively, the child can qualify for citizenship by descent if the parent had been resident in Singapore for a total of five years or more cumulatively over his or her entire lifetime up to the birth of the child.  The Bill to amend this part of the Constitution will be tabled in Parliament by the end of this Committee of Supply.

     Mustafa exploits the system efficiency of Singapore to maximum advantage.  I spoke to Mustaq Ahmad, the CEO.  There are many Indians from India now living here and they are a little suspicious about the milk that we get from Australia and New Zealand because of what goes into the feed.  They prefer to get milk from India where the cows are sacred and fed on hay and grass.  So, he said, every week, several containers of fresh milk arrive from India, and he is the sole supplier and, therefore his Indian milk commands good prices.  He can do that because we are a transportation hub.  In the same way, we must think of other ways to make use of our hub position to lower the cost of retail in Singapore.  And one obvious sector to look at is in

Column: 1451

warehouse sales.  Companies like IKEA are very interested. And MTI is now looking at how we can review the rules which presently inhibit the establishment of warehouse outlets in Singapore.  We should aim to become the warehouse outlet of South East Asia.

 

Manufacturing

 

     In manufacturing, many Members asked whether we are succeeding in moving up the value chain.  We are making steady progress.  Let me just cite two examples.      In electronics, we have been able to move into new technologies, like Organic Light Emitting Diodes (OLEDs).  Organic Light Emitting Diodes will enable screens to be flexible one day.  Ness Display, a South Korean start-up, has announced a S$123 million investment to manufacture Organic Light Emitting Diodes for the global market.   It expects to produce 18 million OLEDs by 2006, and the factory will employ 300 people.  Another example is Hitachi's Global Storage Technologies which has decided to make Singapore its only server hard disk drive manufacturing site in the world.  So we are holding our own in electronics. 

 

    The biomedical sector continues to show impressive growth, accounting for 19% of the total value added in the manufacturing sector last year.   We are beginning to attract investments in biomedical research.   An unexpected benefit of SARS last year was the boost it gave to this sector.  Because of the excellent work done by our research institutes and our hospitals, our international reputation went up many notches.  The US Center for Disease Control (CDC) is partnering MOH to set up the Regional Emerging Diseases Intervention (REDI) Centre to make Singapore a key node in the global disease surveillance network.  Roche Diagnostics formed a collaboration with the Genome Institute of Singapore to develop a SARS

Column: 1452

diagnostic kit.  ISIS Singapore, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Isis Pharmaceuticals, announced its intention to broaden its micro-RNA and anti-sense drug discovery programmes to target the coronavirus associated with SARS.

 

     And because of the good progress we made, we are now looking at the next phase for the Biopolis.  While the direct employment in the biomedical sector is not high, it will enhance the healthcare sector which employs many Singaporeans.  It will also create jobs in supporting industries.  For example, in the Biopolis, we have built a complex for three hundred thousand mice.  There are mice and mice, but these are special ones.  Many companies will locate research activities in Singapore in order to have access to this mice facility.   And we are one of the few countries in Asia which can run such a facility to international scientific and ethical standards.  While in other countries, mice are vermin to be rid of, in Singapore, our mice constitute valuable intellectual property.  And this is because of the integrity of the system which we operate.

 

R&D

 

     Ms Olivia Lum asked how our research and development strategies benefit the private sector.   She is right to point out that the private sector must take the lead in developing technology and A*STAR must work with the private sector.  They are not doing too badly.  Our gross expenditure in R&D, which is the supply side measure, is now 2.2% of GDP which is close to the OECD average of 2.3%.  And A*STAR's 12 research institutes strengthen our key industries by conducting research in cutting-edge niche areas.   And without A*STAR our biomedical sector could never have taken off.

 

     A*STAR has also created an innovative programme to help promising

Column: 1453

local companies upgrade their capabilities through a programme called GET-Up (Growing Enterprises with Technology Upgrade).  Since its launch early last year, many companies have benefited.

 

     I agree with Ms Olivia Lum that our research institutes should encourage the commercialisation of the technology that is developed.  But as the research institutes use taxpayers' money for their research, they must balance the commercial interest of the company they helped with the overall national interest.  As to whom the benefits of IP generated should accrue, it is a subject for negotiation.   If there are good reasons why a particular IP arrangement is not suitable, A*STAR is prepared to vary on a case-by-case basis.  But I think we got to look at a particular case in mind before we can settle on what particular structure is suitable.  But A*STAR will be flexible.

 

SMEs and traditional industries

 

     Dr Tan Boon Wan and Mr Arthur Fong were concerned about the prospects for SMEs and traditional industries.  We have got to help them adjust to changing trends; but we should not be helping them to stay put.   Because when the tide of globalisation is coming in, staying put can be disastrous.  We will of course consult them, stay in touch with them to know how they can be helped. 

 

    Let me just cite the textiles and apparel industry of an industry which we have helped and which will now see a new spring because of the US-Singapore FTA.   It was once the mainstay of manufacturing in Singapore when we were industrialising.  But since then, many of our companies have gone overseas, in order to take advantage of quotas granted to developing countries.  But come next year, the quota system will end, and this

Column: 1454

will transform the global industry.  Textiles and apparel exports to developed country markets will then be subject to tariffs.  So this has opened up an opportunity for us because under the US-Singapore FTA, we can export a specified volume of textiles and apparel products to the US tariff-free.  The industry now contributes about $260 million to GDP and employs 10,000 workers.    It moves quickly, and if we help them to move quickly, they can preserve for themselves a valuable niche for many years to come.

 

     And EDB will help them upgrade their technology and to grow the higher end fashion and merchandising industry in order to strengthen the overall performance of the cluster.  The industry is also working closely with WDA to train locals for the many jobs that are available.  And it is an industry which is constantly short of workers, despite the fact that for years and years, we have been saying that it is a declining industry.

 

Services

 

   Let me now talk a little about services,  because services will generate a lot of the jobs that we need to have in Singapore and which concern many of us.  Members have tabled cuts on tourism which will be taken up later by MOS Vivian Balakrishnan.  But tourism is one area which has shown great resilience last year, despite the disaster of SARS.   The industry pulled together and, together with STB, responded brilliantly.  In one month, the market plunged by over 70%.  We introduced an assistance package in April, got everybody together, set standards, took temperatures, applied stickers and when the crisis passed, we launched a campaign called Singapore Roars!   And by the fourth quarter, visitor arrivals were back to normal, in some cases, exceeding last year.    And this year, we expect visitor arrivals to grow by 24%, of course, barring unforeseen circumstances.

 

Column: 1455

    In healthcare, despite increasing competition from regional countries, we are holding our own as a recognised centre for quality healthcare.  Last year, we launched the Singapore Medicine initiative and attracted more than 200,000 foreign patients.  We are targeting to serve one million patients by 2012.

 

      In education, Singapore already has 10 world-class universities based here.  But the demand for good education in the region across a wide range is simply insatiable.  So many members of the middle classes in China, in India, in Vietnam, wanting something better for their children.   We must get into this industry which is worth hundreds of billions of dollars.  EDB has launched a multi-agency initiative called the Global Schoolhouse.  And our target is to attract by 2012 an additional 100,000 full-fee paying foreign students and 100,000 regional executives here for executive training.

To strengthen the strong reputation of a Singapore education, SPRING is working on an accreditation system for educational institutions.  This additional boost to tourism from healthcare and education will help the retail sector and benefit SMEs, meeting some of Mr Arthur Fong's and Mdm Halimah's concerns. 

 

5.00 pm

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh asked how Singapore will respond to some of the new challenges posed by our neighbours.  He cited Thailand announcing that it has every intention to take oil trading sector away from Singapore.   Thailand's value proposition, eg, its land bridge across the Kra Isthmus, is, in part, driven by the desire of Japan, China and Korea for energy security.  They get most of their oil from the Middle East.  But oil trading, bunkering and refining are traditional strengths of Singapore, going back a long

Column: 1456

time.  Ships have called on Singapore for bunkering since the days of the steamship.  Over the years, we have built Singapore  to be the third biggest oil-trading centre in the world after London and New York.  Oil is such a strategic resource and the investments are so huge, companies like ExxonMobil and Shell recruit very bright minds to analyse trends in politics, economics and technology.  Having been based here for so long, I do not think they are going to move away quickly just because new incentives have been announced.   This is an area where we have deep expertise, and we have no intention at all to cede our lead in this sector.  Nevertheless, we must watch the competition very closely, watch our costs, and continue to provide a business-friendly,  family-friendly and safe environment for international companies.  We are studying Thailand's moves closely and, where necessary, we will respond to those moves in a timely manner. 

 

     We are also breaking new grounds in the creative services.  A younger generation of Singaporean creative talent is emerging, sometimes not well understood by their parents.  In fact, the contribution of Singaporeans can increasingly be seen in many world-class productions.  Take National Geographic Channel, which now screens globally 10 original documentaries, of which six were produced by Singapore firms.  This series was commissioned by the Documentary Production Fund, jointly launched by National Geographic and EDB.  This partnership will provide more opportunities for Singapore-based production talents to work with and learn from the best in the business.  We are also attracting investments by top-notch creative companies.  Weta Workshop, the producer of "Lord of the Rings", plans to co-produce an animated TV series with Singapore Technologies' subsidiary, IV Labs.  It is training up to six Singapore professionals who will form a core production team  here.  Koei, a Japanese

Column: 1457

company better known for its blockbuster games "Romance of The Three Kingdoms" and "Dynasty Warriors", will be establishing a 21-man games development studio here in October. 

 

     Mr Leong Horn Kee asked if we were doing enough to build a vibrant business environment so that we can be the London of Asia.  We have already done many things, and we will do many more.  On Wednesday, DPM Lee spoke about bungees and home breweries.  We are liberalising in a deliberate and controlled manner, sometimes experimenting along the way.  Take One North, our new integrated science park at Buona Vista.  It is going to be a test bed for us.  Earlier I talked about the mice city, which we would not have allowed it elsewhere, and which would have unsettled many Members of Parliament.  We are going to introduce personal transporters like the Segway at One North.  Under existing regulations, the Segway will have no market in Singapore.  If it uses the roads, it needs a COE.  So, it is a non-starter.  And because it is motorised, it is not allowed for use on our jogging and cycling tracks.  So, the only place you can use it in Singapore is in your own private compound.  And it costs too much for you to keep it as a toy back home.  We are going to allow it at One North.  We will allow personal transporters on pedestrian walkways and certain designated roads, and then let us watch what happens.  If there are problems, then we may tighten the rules.  If there are no problems, then maybe we can relax the rules for other parts of Singapore.  And there will be other experiments that we will conduct at One North.

 

      On Sentosa Cove and the Southern Islands, we will turn a part of Singapore into an iconic international resort and residential development.  On Wednesday, DPM Lee announced that we will allow

Column: 1458

the sale of landed properties at Sentosa Cove to foreigners.  Sentosa Cove is a distinctive waterfront residential development, complete with marinas and clubhouses.  In the coming months, we will proceed with the sale of more land at Sentosa Cove.  We intend to integrate the development of the Southern Islands with Sentosa Cove and the rest of Sentosa.  The Islands will be linked to Sentosa either by boat or by a bridge.  For Members who are not familiar with the Southern Islands, I have circulated two maps.  As you can see, the Southern Islands have already been enlarged by reclamation.

 

     We will create on Sentosa and the Southern Islands a world-class resort and residential development of over 500 hectares.  There will be a comprehensive range of facilities, including beautiful beaches, hotels, private residential homes, marinas, sports complexes, convention centres, health spas, retail and F&B outlets, venues for  international shows and theme attractions.   We are keeping an open mind on what to have in this development, including the possibility of having a casino.  Of course, if we decide to have a casino, we will need to put in place control measures to limit its access by Singaporeans and to make sure that there is no organised crime.

 

     We will engage international consultants to help us map out the possibilities.  An illustration of what is possible can be found at Atlantis on Paradise Island in the Bahamas.  This is only an illustration, and what we create eventually will probably not look anything at all like Paradise Island.  It will be, and it will have to be, uniquely Singapore.  What we envisage is an international facility separate from Singapore but accessible to all Singaporeans, with more relaxed rules to attract international talent, visitors and investments.  It will help us maintain our position among the front rank of cities in 21st century Asia.

FTAs

 

     Many Members talked about our Free Trade Agreements.  To-date, we have signed FTAs with the US, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and the European Free Trade Association consisting of Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland.  Together, they account for over 27% of our domestic exports.   We are also deepening our economic ties with China and India and working on stronger links to the EU.  With India, we hope to conclude our FTA later this year.  We will begin negotiations with China later this year once the goods chapter of the ASEAN-China FTA has been concluded in the middle of this year.  We are in the course of negotiating or launching new negotiations with many countries, eg, Canada, Mexico - although that has slowed down - with Chile, Sri Lanka, Bahrain, Jordan and Panama.  Pakistan and the Ukraine have expressed interest. 

 

     We did not set out to be an FTA hub, but we are fast becoming one.  To our pleasant surprise, a number of countries have indicated strong interest in having FTAs with us, because they feel that this will enhance their ability to attract trade and investment.  But, really, we are the ones who benefit, because they have tariffs while we have none.  Therefore, we welcome their requests because, as an international hub for many businesses, the more FTAs we have, the better.  This is not to say that we are not committed to the WTO and the multilateral system.  But we know that whatever WTO can achieve, we need much more.  Nevertheless, we are one of the most ardent supporters of the WTO. 

 

     Mr Leong Horn Kee, Mr Inderjit Singh and Mdm Halimah asked whether we were giving away too much in our FTAs when we negotiate with large countries like the US.  I do not believe so.  For goods, we have nothing to give away because we have no tariffs, except beer.  

Column: 1460

The opening up of our financial markets is consistent with our own  liberalisation plans.  Selectively opening up the legal sector helps us make Singapore a legal hub, which is good for Singapore's competitiveness.   To answer Mdm Halimah's point, it is for Singapore law firms to decide whether or not to enter into JVs with foreign law firms.  So, the market will work itself out.  The implementation of a more rigorous Intellectual Property Regime, which is an important aspect of our FTA with the US, enhances Singapore's attractiveness as a place to invest and do business and, in fact, following that FTA, we have attracted more interest from companies wanting to manage their IP out of Singapore. 

 

     On issues which are of fundamental importance to us, we have stood our ground.  For example, we would not agree on giving up our right to control the movement of capital in a crisis although we were prepared to limit the circumstances under which this right could be exercised.  On chewing gum, we have made some minor concessions, but the basic position, as you know, has not changed at all.

 

     Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Inderjit Singh have asked how we have benefited from our FTAs, and others have asked how we should help our SMEs benefit from FTAs.  Trade volumes have increased as a result.  Domestic exports to Japan, New Zealand and EFTA have all gone up.  With this growth come job opportunities.  For example, plastics exports to Japan have increased by a whopping 75% since our FTA with Japan came into force in November 2002.  Processed food exports to New Zealand have gone up by more than 60% since the FTA with New Zealand came into force in January 2001. 

 

     Our FTAs not only create new jobs.  In some cases, they also help us keep jobs in

Column: 1461

traditional industries, like the textiles and apparel industry.   We have no industrial policy to phase out particular industries, except for non-economic reasons, like our policy not to have pig farming in Singapore.   Otherwise, we stand ready to be surprised by the market.  As I mentioned earlier, for years we predicted the demise of the textile industry.  Now, it is having a second lease of life.  Where there are opportunities in our FTAs to help traditional industries stay competitive, we will, of course, seize them.  We are not able to estimate the actual number of jobs created, which was what Mdm Halimah asked, because there are so many factors involved and it is not easy to isolate the FTA effect. 

 

     But we know that our FTAs do benefit SMEs, a point raised by Dr Ahmad Magad and Mr Wee Siew Kim.  How do we know?  For our FTAs with Japan and Australia, companies have to apply to Singapore Customs for certificates of origin before they can enjoy the preferential tariffs.  Although this applies only to the export of goods, it gives us an indicator of the extent to which SMEs are exploiting the FTAs.  15% of the applications were from SMEs.  Of course, this figure is still low and should be improved, but it is encouraging that more SMEs now are learning new tricks. 

 

      Our FTAs also bind our partners to keep their markets open.  This protects us from certain kinds of policy changes and it is a benefit which we do not realise until something happens.  For example, when Singapore signed the FTA with the US, the US was granting 195,000 H1B visas worldwide a year for professionals.  In October last year, because of political pressure against outsourcing, this was sharply reduced to 65,000.  We are protected because, under the FTA, we are guaranteed 5,400 visas, which is not a small percentage of the total.  But I do

Column: 1462

not have information on how many of these visas have actually been issued to Singaporeans because this is done by the US Government, not by us.

 

     Another example of how the FTA with the US has benefited us is the outsourcing of US government procurement.  Recently, the US Senate passed a Bill banning the subcontracting of government jobs to foreign companies.  When I was in India recently, one businessman  who heard that our FTA  protected companies here against such restrictions, he immediately wondered whether he should not transfer more of his operations to Singapore so that he can qualify to be an Indian company in Singapore with substantial interest in Singapore.

 

     So, you see, in ways direct and indirect, these Free Trade Agreements help us maintain our international competitiveness.  And we negotiate these FTAs precisely

to benefit our businesses.  I agree with Mr Leong, Dr Ahmad Magad and Mr Wee Siew Kim on the importance of educating our business community. This is top priority for MTI and its agencies. The reason why we move legislation to create the SBF is because we needed a counterpart apex organisation for consultations on trade policies and trade negotiations. 

 

5.15 pm

 

    For all FTAs initiated since January last year, we have conducted intensive pre-negotiation consultations with SBF and various business associations.  We also conduct, on a continuing basis, technical briefings tailored to particular business sectors because the money is in the details.  We are organising a FTA Day next month to inaugurate a series of hands-on workshops and take companies by their hands, as it were through the rules of origin, compliance and qualification.  To ensure easy access to information on FTAs, MTI created a

Column: 1463

comprehensive FTA website which includes an interactive tariff savings calculator. 

 

     A number of MPs spoke about the importance of creating the external space for the expansion of our second wing.  We talked about ASEAN, India, China and other countries.  ASEAN will always be our inner circle.  For this reason, we have been very active in promoting the integration of the ASEAN economies. When we started with our FTA policy, many of our neighbours were unsettled, thinking that we are breaking ranks.  They did not believe our assurances.  But having watched our moves and having watched all the initiatives that we have taken to strengthen ASEAN, they have come to the conclusion that we meant well.  Indeed, we have started a cascade of FTA initiatives in ASEAN and beyond.   Thailand was an early convert and even Malaysia now has joined the bandwagon.  I would say that, on the whole, ASEAN countries realise the importance of  FTAs and how the bilateral FTAs that Singapore has can also benefit them. In fact, the Vietnamese probe us all the time about our FTA initiatives and ask us how they can benefit from them. So does Indonesia. 

 

    With Malaysia under PM Abdullah Badawi, we are hopeful of a fresh start.  Officials are now studying how we can enhance the Malaysia-Singapore Third Country Fund so that companies from both sides can work together to explore opportunities in third countries.  But as to whether we will ever have a high speed rail link up the Peninsular to Thailand, Indo-China and China, a point raised by Mr Leong Horn Kee, I think that depends on whether there is sufficient political will in ASEAN to work together. If there is, this will happen.  It makes a lot of economic sense. 

 

    Our links with Thailand are also growing. Our links with Vietnam are

Column: 1464

blossoming.  Vietnam is important to us because Vietnam's economy and our economy are complementary.  Our Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park in Ho Chi Minh City is going to phase three.  We lifted visa requirements late last year and opened a tourism information centre in Ho Chi Minh City to attract middle class Vietnamese to come to Singapore for entertainment, healthcare and education.

 

    We are working with Vietnam on two-legged investments.  In other words, what we are trying to do is to encourage MNCs, who want alternatives to China and Latin America, to consider Singapore and Vietnam as one economic entity - put something here and put something there - but only one virtual investment agency to service them, ie, EDB working with its counterpart and resolving internal difficulties.  Recently, when Prime Minister Phan Van Khai was in Singapore, the Vietnamese gave in-principle approval to four companies.  We hope that if this works, we can increase the number.

 

    With Indonesia, we have been doing something similar for Batam and Bintan.  Once elections are over, we will do more with those islands.  Even with what we have done so far, we have helped to create 180,000 industrial jobs and help Indonesia greatly increased its export earnings. 

 

    Many provinces of Sumatra are now seeking direct economic links to Singapore because under the new dispensation, with power and authority devolved to the provinces, they want to have their own direct outlets. To my surprise last year, I was invited to join the nine governors of Sumatra for their regular meetings. I have attended two so far. We are training their officials and a number of them, like Jambi, South Sumatra, have set up offices in Singapore.  Just last week, the Governor of West Sumatra told me that he will also open an office here.  But our  interest goes beyond Sumatra.  We

Column: 1465

welcome direct links with all the provinces of Indonesia. 

 

    This evening the Esplanade will be premiering a threatre production of the epic history of the Sulawesi people, I La Galligo.  It is a world-class production which will start here and travel to London, Europe and New York.  I wrote a note to Pak Yusuf Kalla, Coordinating Minister for People's Welfare, I said, "Look, I know you are in the middle of elections, but, if by chance, you have a few hours to spare, come, and bring your friends along."  He is coming.  He is flying here at about 5 o'clock this afternoon, seeing the show which will last four hours, and at midnight, he is flying to Sulawesi for his election campaign.  This really touched my heart because when I invited him, I did not really expect him to come.  He is coming because firstly, it is a good production.  But, secondly, I believe that some of the leaders in Sulawesi are coming here because they want links with Singapore.  We should welcome them and help them.  So long as these links are economic and not political, Jakarta will not object.  But we have to manage this carefully.

 

    Let me for the next few minutes talk a little about China and India which we will continue to talk about in this House for years to come because these are two realities which are growing and should become more and more important to us. 

 

    In China now, we already have a huge account and it is growing strongly.  At the end of 2002, our cumulative investments in China reached $17 billion. Our trade with China grew by 31% last year with non-oil domestic exports growing by 34%. As has happened again and again in history, the growth of China will bring prosperity to Southeast Asia.  We must position ourselves for this future.

    This year marks the 10th anniversary of the Suzhou Industrial Park.  I disagree with Mr Leong Horn Kee that it was all an unhappy experience and we should move on. There were difficulties, but the Chinese now see SIP as an icon of our good political and economic relations.  Suzhou today attracts more investments than Pudong. When we speak to the leaders of Suzhou, they said one reason is because of SIP. SIP's strong performance today is a fruit of great efforts put in by both sides.  The original 70 square kilometres allocated for the project is now nearly fully developed and the Chinese are proposing to enlarge it.  The Consortium intends to list a joint venture company next year. 

 

    Apart from Jiangsu, we have strong links with other provinces. Last year, we set up new business councils with Liaoning and Zhejiang.  We are beginning to reap the benefits of China's externalisation strategy which was a proposal by Hu Jintao when he visited us last year when he said that Chinese companies should use Singapore as a base for their internationalisation.  Last year, a record of 13 Chinese companies launched their IPOs at the Singapore Exchange. We encourage Chinese companies to make use of Singapore as a base for regionalisation and internationalisation.  When PM Goh met PM Wen Jiabao in November last year, they agreed to the establishment of a Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation (JCBC) to be chaired by DPM Lee and Chinese Vice Premier Wu Yi.  The inaugural meeting will be held in May.  The two PMs also agreed to a full programme of cooperation, including the establishment of a China Business Centre, a Chinese Cultural and Media Centre and a Centre for Chinese Medicine in Singapore.

 

    Now turning to India. India is another country on the move.  Last year, the

Column: 1467

growth rate was over 7%, maybe even 8%. The BJP Government is now planning on the basis of India growing at 8% a year, which is quite remarkable, considering that even 10 years ago, people were talking about the Hindu growth rate of 3-4%.

 

    India is increasingly looking eastwards. We have become an important partner of India and we expect the negotiations for our Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement to be concluded later this year.  India is also negotiating an FTA with ASEAN.

 

    Even as Singapore companies are looking at trade and investment opportunities in India, Indian companies are looking at Singapore as a regional base for East and Southeast Asia. All the top 20 Indian software companies have offices here.  An increasing number of Indian companies are showing up in EDB's client list.  They are beginning to invest in manufacturing in Singapore. Think about it - we, with our high cost, are attracting Indian investments in manufacturing.  Let me just give one example. There are not many examples yet, but let me provide one interesting example.  Next week, an Indian drug packaging company called Bilcare will invest $20 million to set up a factory here with both manufacturing and R&D facilities.  It will provide world-class pharma packaging components.  Bilcare will use its plant to roll out some of its latest technologies for markets in Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam and China.

 

    We have, in the last two years, devoted considerable efforts to enlarge Singapore's external space and to help Singapore companies take advantage of this external space.  I would like to assure Mrs Lim Hwee Hua that it is not just IE Singapore.  Yes, IE Singapore should provide a one-stop service centre but the whole Ministry is involved and all the economic agencies are involved in this effort.  The world is changing.  There are

Column: 1468

new opportunities and there are new dangers, and our radar must be spinning 360 degrees. 

 

    We are helping our companies to form consortiums.  This is not in the business culture here.  But overseas, each is too small to compete, often times.  So we have given incentives - we give grants, and urge them to combine. Mr Leong Horn Kee proposed that we also confer them tax advantages.  I am not sure whether these are needed with our new territorial tax regime.  But we will look at what the practical problems are.  If we need to improve the incentives, we will do so.  But getting our companies to go overseas is a very important part of our future.  And even more important is getting our young people to broaden their mindset and to go overseas and take their chances.  There are many problems that we got to solve to facilitate this.  In the end, it is whether they have the spirit and that drive. 

 

    Yes, we must look after their children's education, enable them to plug out of the Singapore system and plug back in when they come back.  I believe some of the changes taking place in the Education Ministry will facilitate this portability.  There are more and more private Singapore-type schools being established all over Asia.  This is a tribute to the Singapore education system.  They also provide a good facility for Singaporean parents who work in those countries.

Entrepreneurship

   

     Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio):  Sir, entrepreneurship has indeed become an important agenda for all of us and we need to address a few issues.  At the policy level, I have very little to say because I am really pleased at the rate at which things have changed.  One of the

Column: 1469

With $25 million set aside over five years, it will provide matching funding to IHLs to help seed their students' business ventures. We hope to fund some 100 ventures per year, and provide at least 200 students with on-the-ground start-up experience. While we hope that some will succeed, equally important is that those who do not

Column: 1489

succeed the first time will be wiser when they take on their next venture.  MTI and SPRING have already been working closely with the IHLs, and ETDF will be rolled out in May.

 

      We hope that by doing this, we will have more people like Ms Huang Aiting.   I met her at the Shell LiveWIRE Young Business Start-up awards in October last year. And she impressed me.   An alumnus of the LaSalle-SIA College of the Arts, she is the creative talent behind WOMB Wardrobe.   Her creations - clothes and fashion accessories - have a certain primal energy about them.   Not surprisingly, she won the top award.   She spoke to me after the awards, and she said that when she started, she simply did it out of 'guts and passion'. We want more young people like that, gutsy and passionate.

 

     Later this year, we will be holding the inaugural ACE BlueSky Festival, to celebrate entrepreneurship. This is likely the first time that most of the entrepreneurship groups in Singapore are coming together, and the Festival will cover all aspects of entrepreneurship, including social entrepreneurship. ACE will work closely with other private sector organisations, such as the Young Entrepreneurs' Organisation, the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, and many others on this. I hope that the Festival will also provide a platform for these groups to come together in the future to share resources and work on collaborative projects.

 

Regulatory environment - pro-enterprise mindset

 

     Let me now turn to our efforts to promote a pro-enterprise regulatory environment.   Dr Ahmad Magad has spoken on this, that we need to cut the red tape. Mr Ang Mong Seng has said that the civil servants need to have a pro-

Column: 1490

enterprise mindset.   I agree.  I think the most significant measure here is DPM Lee's announcement in his Budget speech that henceforth, the default key for the regulatory agencies will be set at "Yes", as long as the entrepreneurial activity in question does not cause unmanageable problems or harm to others. This must be so, if we want Singaporeans to discover new frontiers.   Mr Inderjit Singh suggests that Government agencies consider the cost impact on businesses when new laws are formulated. He would be pleased to know that this is indeed what is being done now.   This is something that is looked into every time we are formulating a new law.

 

     To give greater impetus to the existing review mechanisms, the Rules Action Crucible of ACE, led by Patrick Daniel, will be commissioning an annual pro-enterprise ranking of Government regulatory agencies. The survey of businesses will measure regulatory agencies in terms of compliance costs, regulatory obstacles, transparency, customer responsiveness, rules review and pro-enterprise orientation. The top ranking agencies will be announced at the ACE BlueSky Festival. By doing so, we seek to recognise those who have effectively adopted a pro-enterprise mindset and encourage other agencies to do likewise.

 

SME financing made easy - in a market based way

 

     Many Members have spoken on access to financing.  It is an important area.  It is a critical area.  Dr Gan See Khem, Mr Inderjit Singh and Mr Arthur Fong have spoken on the need to improve access to financing. I agree.

 

     The ACE Finance Action Crucible, led by Mr Inderjit Singh, has been pro-active in exploring different financing avenues and introducing a number of initiatives last year. They have done a lot of work, and they ought to be commended. They

Column: 1491

launched the Deal Flow Connection last July, to serve as a platform to link investors with companies that require financing. Since then, it has facilitated over 370 matches between entrepreneurs and financiers.

 

    Over the past year, equity financing for start-ups has also improved. The Government's approach is to make financing for start-ups and SMEs easier, in a market based way. An example of this is the Start-up EnterprisE Development Scheme (SEEDS).   Instead of civil servants making the venture investment decisions where they have no expertise, the Government relies on third-party funding to provide market validation of the company's investment viability. Such independent party validation is valuable and this is why I am reluctant to modify this to include money invested by the firm's founders, as some have suggested.

 

     Now, SEEDS has been successful, investing in over 100 companies since its launch in October 2001. One SEEDS company, RADIXS Pte Ltd, was founded in 1999 by two 21-year olds, R Chandrasekar (Chandra) and Sam Hon Kong Lum.  Last year, the company launched the world's first universal mobile operating system, known as the Motion eXperience Interface (MXI). MXI has the capability to deliver desktop content and applications written for other operating systems to handheld devices, without any redevelopment or porting. The technology is currently being tested by SingTel and Sun Microsystems, and has captured the interest of major global mobile operators, Fortune 500 technology vendors and enterprises. Following the success of SEEDS, the scheme has now been extended to innovative start-ups in non-technology industries.

      In the same vein, the Technopreneur Investment Incentive has been expanded

to non-tech sectors, and renamed the Enterprise Investment Incentive. Mr Singh also asked the Government to consider deploying future technopreneurship promotion funds to many small funds managed by the private sector. This is already being done. The US$1.3 billion Technopreneurship Investment Fund (TIF) is a fund-of-funds, which invests in private venture capital firms. So far, more than US$230 million from the TIF has been invested in Singapore start-ups and companies.

 

 

     In the coming year, there will be a number of new initiatives to improve debt financing.  In September 2002, we started the pilot Loan Insurance Scheme (LIS).  This has proven to be helpful in meeting the short-term financing needs of SMEs.  We will, therefore, be looking to expand the LIS, to provide about $500 million of loans over five years.  The range of indemnity, facilities and PFIs will also be increased.  In particular, we have taken in feedback, and will include loans for internationalisation.  Once these details are confirmed with the PFIs and insurance underwriters, we will be launching the expanded LIS in the next few months.

 

     In response to a recommendation by the ERC Subcommittee on Entrepreneurship and Internationalisation, a new scheme, the Technology Credit Programme, will be piloted later this year.  EDB is exploring and working with specialist lenders to provide loans to technology start-ups under this scheme.  Unlike conventional lenders that rely on collateral to make loans, these specialist lenders will rely on their understanding of underlying business models, intellectual capital and their potential.  As this scheme develops, we will look to extend it to non-technology companies, as we have done with the other financing schemes.

 

     The Government will also be embarking on the SME Loan Securitisation

Column: 1493

project this year, which Mr Inderjit Singh mentioned just now.  It will leverage on the bond markets to reduce the credit risks for lending banks.  In the process, we hope to open up financing to potentially under-served SMEs, such as start-ups without established track records and SMEs that lack collateral.  The Government has already been in extensive discussions with banks on this.  It is anticipated that the securitisation issue will be in the size of at least $300 million.  This will be launched by the end of this year.

 

     We continue to welcome new suggestions on how we can improve access to financing.  Mr Sin Boon Ann has mentioned the possibility of setting up credit co-operatives.  I will ask the Finance Action Crucible, headed by Mr Inderjit Singh, to work with SPRING to look into this.

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh has also suggested that the interest rates for LEFS loans be determined by the PFIs, instead of being fixed by SPRING, and that LEFS be made available for trading loans.  The expanded LIS will cater for trading loans.  We will also study further if LEFS can accommodate such loans, and if variable interest rates can be introduced for LEFS.  This should be completed within the next few months.

 

     Concern was also raised by Mr Inderjit Singh about the need for a Chapter 11 type regime in Singapore to help companies restructure, and avoid the situation where banks go for winding up at the first sign of problems in the SMEs.  Our insolvency laws already provide for corporate re-organisation, such as schemes of arrangement and judicial management, and they have been used by creditors.  The Government is also reviewing the merits of a US Chapter 11 process, a follow up to the Company

Column: 1494

Legislation and Regulatory Framework Committee Report.  There have also been calls for the setting up of a private equity exchange.  We are supportive of this.  Some private sector parties are already exploring this, and we will work with the relevant Government agency to facilitate this effort, where necessary.

 

     Dr Gan See Khem and Mr Arthur Fong brought up some difficulties which some SMEs had in financing.  We need to draw a distinction here.  If there is a systemic market failure in terms of financing, the Government will intervene.  However, at any moment in time, a particular firm might fail to receive financing in the market.  This is not a failure of the market.   This is a normal working of the market, that some companies will not get financing.

 

     Mr Arthur Fong mentioned micro loans.  The success rate in terms of approval is about 70%.  So, it is not true that it has not been successful.  About 70% received that.  In terms of LEFS, about 80-85% gets approval.  But we will constantly review and ensure that these schemes are relevant and effective.  We will take note of what he has said because we want to constantly improve on this.  But we need to bear in mind that, in the normal working of the market, definitely some firms will not get funding, and that is not the sign of a market failure.

 

     Mr Ang Mong Seng brought up the difficulties of some companies which have insufficient track record or turnover, and that they cannot register.  He will be pleased to know that, currently, companies with insufficient track record or turnover can register as a Government supplier to participate in Government tenders, as long as they have the requisite paid-up capital.  When Government agencies process tender applications by start-ups, we will look at the entrepreneur's track record, if the

Column: 1495

company he heads is too new to have a track record.

 

     However, the Government can only lead by example here.  It cannot mandate that bigger companies consider smaller companies when issuing contracts.  These are commercial decisions.  The competition law will not address this.  Nor is it meant for cases where bigger companies take ideas from smaller companies when they negotiate.  The proper protection for that is through the use of confidentiality agreements and intellectual property law.  What the competition law can and will do is to target anti-competitive agreements and conduct of companies, such as abuse of dominance, that have significant adverse impact on competition in the market.

 

     The issue of incentives to encourage mergers was raised by Dr John Chen.  This was discussed in the ERC.  The tax accountants we consulted agreed that the cost of M&A between local SMEs is about 2-4% of the transaction value, and that it is not prohibitively high.  More importantly, successful integration depends very much on finding the right partners, rather than tax incentives.  Otherwise, value would be lost, not added, in the merger.  Thus, we feel that mergers are ultimately commercial decisions that should be best left to the private sector.  However, a strong buy-out fund industry can help facilitate this.  In this regard, there are tax incentives to set up private equity funds, including buy-out funds.  Section 13(H) of the Income Tax Act provides exemption on gains from the fund, while the Pioneer Incentive provides exemptions on income derived by the fund manager.

 

     To successfully penetrate overseas markets, our SMEs will need to differentiate themselves.  Thus, I agree with Dr Ahmad Magad that we need to promote innovation among SMEs.  This was the impetus behind the Growing

Column: 1496

Enterprises Technology Upgrading (GET-Up) programme, which Minister George Yeo mentioned earlier.

 

     Dr Ahmad Magad also mentioned it is important that we retain talent, if the SMEs are to grow.  I agree with him.  SPRING has been helping SMEs to improve their HR practices through the People Developer Standard.  This offers companies a systemic process to review their people practices, develop staff and improve training effectiveness.  The results have been encouraging, as SMEs make up about 50% of the 2,000 organisations participating in the People Developer programme.

 

     Mr Inderjit Singh has asked for a one-stop shop to serve SMEs even better.  We have also received similar feedback from groups, such as the Feedback Groups on Economic Development and SMEs.  We agree that we should constantly seek to improve our service delivery to SMEs.  To this end, we will strengthen SPRING, which will work together with Government agencies, such as EDB and IE Singapore, to develop an SME One Stop.  This will help SMEs find the right information and assistance, reduce the time and resources needed to carry out Government transactions, and get closure with the other agencies.

 

     This, however, will be a challenge.  There are about 110,000 SMEs in Singapore at different stages of development, with very diverse needs.  And we have to work with finite resources.  So, the SME One Stop will be primarily web-based, and supplemented with a call centre and face-to-face consultation services.  The web portal will enable SMEs to obtain all the information they need, as well as apply for licences and Government assistance schemes without having to go to different agencies.  The portal will be designed with SMEs in mind.  It will be simple to navigate and easy to understand and use.

To develop this customised portal for SMEs, SPRING will conduct a pilot study with a group of between 300 and 400 SMEs to better understand their needs.  But we recognise that, for some SMEs, they will still prefer to make a call or have face-to-face consultations.  But because more resources are needed to provide that sort of service, we might need to levy a fee when it comes to those services. 

 

Quality service - a way of life

 

     One sector dominated by SMEs is the retail sector, which Mr Arthur Fong brought up just now.  The retail sector was badly affected by SARS last year, but it is now showing signs of recovery.  However, more fundamental issues remain to be tackled.  The retail sector suffers from a lack of innovation and product differentiation, insufficient customer segmentation, as well as increasing regional competition.  Smaller HDB retailers, in particular, are handicapped by the lack of economies of scale.

 

     How can we help them?  The Retail Academy of Singapore, which is co-funded by the Government and the private sector, provides training for retailers to upgrade their skills and improve retailing standards.  The Retail Promotion Centre provides skills workshops for HDB retailers, for example, on creating better retail ambience, as well as projects, such as the Heartland Shopping Surprise, which involved 2,000 retailers at about 20 town centres island-wide.

 

     Some HDB retailers have already seized the initiative to upgrade.  One example is Mr Seow Hong Kheng of Tong Seng Huat in Toa Payoh.  After becoming a franchisee of I-Econ last November, his outlet has been able to attract more customers, especially young working adults.  The store layout is now less

Column: 1498

congested, which enables customers to easily locate what they want to buy.  This new look has improved sales by between 10% and 20%.

 

     Ms Irene Ng and Dr Tan Boon Wan brought up questions on the quality of service, and that we need to upgrade it.  I agree with Ms Irene Ng that this problem, like entrepreneurship, is one that actually involves mindsets and societal values.  Our workers must want to provide good service and, as customers, we must appreciate and value the good service that we receive.  

 

     In this respect, STB's Art of Service programme aims to engender an attitude of passion, vocational pride and creativity in the delivery of service among workers.  We also seek to recognise outstanding service through awards, such as the Retail Courtesy Gold Award and the Excellent Service Award.  One good example of this is a SuperStar winner at the 2003 Excellent Service Awards.  Mr Eric Yeong is a taxi driver with TIBS.  One day, he picked up a passenger from Gleneagles.  She was just discharged and had a newborn baby with her, and Eric Yeong drove very carefully through all the road humps, to ensure that she had a safe journey home.  The passenger was so impressed with Eric Yeong that when she wanted to deliver the celebration cakes at the first month, she engaged Eric Yeong again.  Again, Eric Yeong was very solicitous, very careful, very pleasant, that even her friends thought that Eric Yeong was actually her relative.

 

     Sir, in service quality, as in entrepreneurship, the Government can facilitate but, ultimately, it will be our people, service workers such as Eric Yeong, and entrepreneurs such as Aiting, Chandra and Sam, who will make a difference and take us to the next level.  On our part, we will continue to lay the foundation, so that our people can sense and seize opportunities, and realise our

collective vision of a more open, creative and cosmopolitan Singapore.
